fr.sii.ogham.helper.email

Class AssertEmail

  • java.lang.Object
    • fr.sii.ogham.helper.email.AssertEmail

  • public class AssertEmail
extends Object
    Utility class for checking if the received email content is as expected.
    Author:
    Aur√©lien Baudet

    • Method Detail

      • assertEquals

        public static void assertEquals(ExpectedMultiPartEmail expectedEmail,
                                javax.mail.Message actualEmail)
                         throws javax.mail.MessagingException,
                                IOException
        Assert that the fields of the received email are equal to the expected values. The expected email contains several parts (several contents). The received email should also have the equivalent parts. It will check that:
        • The received headers are respected (see assertHeaders(ExpectedEmailHeader, Message))
        • The received message is a Multipart email
        • The number of parts are equal
        • Each received part body equals the expected one (order is important). See assertBody(String, String, boolean)
        • Each received part Mime Type equals the expected one (order is important). See assertMimetype(ExpectedContent, String)

        The checking of the body is done strictly (totally equal).

        Parameters:
        expectedEmail - all the fields with their expected values
        actualEmail - the received email
        Throws:
        javax.mail.MessagingException - when accessing the received email fails
        IOException - when reading the content of the email fails

      • assertEquals

        public static void assertEquals(ExpectedMultiPartEmail expectedEmail,
                                javax.mail.Message[] actualEmails)
                         throws javax.mail.MessagingException,
                                IOException

        Shortcut to simplify unit testing with GreenMail. See assertEquals(ExpectedMultiPartEmail[], Message[]).

        Assert that the fields of the received email are equal to the expected values. The expected email contains several parts (several contents). The received email should also have the equivalent parts. It will check that:
        • The received headers are respected (see assertHeaders(ExpectedEmailHeader, Message))
        • The received message is a Multipart email
        • The number of parts are equal
        • Each received part body equals the expected one (order is important). See assertBody(String, String, boolean)
        • Each received part Mime Type equals the expected one (order is important). See assertMimetype(ExpectedContent, String)

        The checking of the body is done strictly (totally equal).

        Parameters:
        expectedEmail - all the fields with their expected values
        actualEmails - the received email
        Throws:
        javax.mail.MessagingException - when accessing the received email fails
        IOException - when reading the content of the email fails

      • assertEquals

        public static void assertEquals(ExpectedMultiPartEmail[] expectedEmails,
                                javax.mail.Message[] actualEmails)
                         throws javax.mail.MessagingException,
                                IOException
        Assert that each received email content respects the expected one. It ensures that the number of received emails equals to the expected number. Then for each email it calls assertEquals(ExpectedMultiPartEmail, Message) .
        Parameters:
        expectedEmails - the list of expected emails
        actualEmails - the received emails
        Throws:
        javax.mail.MessagingException - when accessing the received email fails
        IOException - when reading the content of the email fails

      • assertEquals

        public static void assertEquals(ExpectedEmail expectedEmail,
                                javax.mail.Message[] actualEmails)
                         throws javax.mail.MessagingException

        Shortcut to simplify unit testing with GreenMail. See assertEquals(ExpectedEmail[], Message[]).

        Assert that the fields of the received email are equal to the expected values. The expected email contains only one part (only one content). It will check that:
        • The received headers are respected (see assertHeaders(ExpectedEmailHeader, Message))
        • The body equals the expected one (order is important). See assertBody(String, String, boolean)
        • The Mime Type equals the expected one (order is important). See assertMimetype(ExpectedContent, String)

        The checking of the body is done strictly (totally equal).

        Parameters:
        expectedEmail - all the fields with their expected values
        actualEmails - the received emails
        Throws:
        javax.mail.MessagingException - when accessing the received email fails

      • assertEquals

        public static void assertEquals(ExpectedEmail[] expectedEmail,
                                javax.mail.Message[] actualEmails)
                         throws javax.mail.MessagingException
        Assert that each received email content respects the expected one. It ensures that the number of received emails equals to the expected number. Then for each email it calls assertEquals(ExpectedEmail, Message) .
        Parameters:
        expectedEmail - the expected email
        actualEmails - the received emails
        Throws:
        javax.mail.MessagingException - when accessing the received email fails

      • assertEquals

        public static void assertEquals(ExpectedEmail expectedEmail,
                                javax.mail.Message actualEmail)
                         throws javax.mail.MessagingException
        Assert that the fields of the received email are equal to the expected values. The expected email contains only one part (only one content). It will check that:
        • The received headers are respected (see assertHeaders(ExpectedEmailHeader, Message))
        • The body equals the expected one (order is important). See assertBody(String, String, boolean)
        • The Mime Type equals the expected one (order is important). See assertMimetype(ExpectedContent, String)

        The checking of the body is done strictly (totally equal).

        Parameters:
        expectedEmail - all the fields with their expected values
        actualEmail - the received email
        Throws:
        javax.mail.MessagingException - when accessing the received email fails

      • assertSimilar

        public static void assertSimilar(ExpectedMultiPartEmail expectedEmail,
                                 javax.mail.Message actualEmail)
                          throws javax.mail.MessagingException,
                                 IOException
        Assert that the fields of the received email are equal to the expected values. The expected email contains several parts (several contents). The received email should also have the equivalent parts. It will check that:
        • The received headers are respected (see assertHeaders(ExpectedEmailHeader, Message))
        • The received message is a Multipart email
        • The number of parts are equal
        • Each received part body equals the expected one (order is important). See assertBody(String, String, boolean)
        • Each received part Mime Type equals the expected one (order is important). See assertMimetype(ExpectedContent, String)

        The checking of the body ignores the new line characters.

        Parameters:
        expectedEmail - all the fields with their expected values
        actualEmail - the received email
        Throws:
        javax.mail.MessagingException - when accessing the received email fails
        IOException - when reading the content of the email fails

      • assertSimilar

        public static void assertSimilar(ExpectedMultiPartEmail expectedEmail,
                                 javax.mail.Message[] actualEmails)
                          throws javax.mail.MessagingException,
                                 IOException

        Shortcut to simplify unit testing with GreenMail. See assertSimilar(ExpectedMultiPartEmail[], Message[]).

        Assert that the fields of the received email are equal to the expected values. The expected email contains several parts (several contents). The received email should also have the equivalent parts. It will check that:
        • The received headers are respected (see assertHeaders(ExpectedEmailHeader, Message))
        • The received message is a Multipart email
        • The number of parts are equal
        • Each received part body equals the expected one (order is important). See assertBody(String, String, boolean)
        • Each received part Mime Type equals the expected one (order is important). See assertMimetype(ExpectedContent, String)

        The checking of the body ignores the new line characters.

        Parameters:
        expectedEmail - all the fields with their expected values
        actualEmails - the received email
        Throws:
        javax.mail.MessagingException - when accessing the received email fails
        IOException - when reading the content of the email fails

      • assertSimilar

        public static void assertSimilar(ExpectedMultiPartEmail[] expectedEmails,
                                 javax.mail.Message[] actualEmails)
                          throws javax.mail.MessagingException,
                                 IOException
        Assert that each received email content respects the expected one. It ensures that the number of received emails equals to the expected number. Then for each email it calls assertSimilar(ExpectedMultiPartEmail, Message) .
        Parameters:
        expectedEmails - the list of expected emails
        actualEmails - the received emails
        Throws:
        javax.mail.MessagingException - when accessing the received email fails
        IOException - when reading the content of the email fails

                          throws javax.mail.MessagingException

        Shortcut to simplify unit testing with GreenMail. See assertSimilar(ExpectedEmail[], Message[]).

        Assert that the fields of the received email are equal to the expected values. The expected email contains only one part (only one content). It will check that:
        • The received headers are respected (see assertHeaders(ExpectedEmailHeader, Message))
        • The body equals the expected one (order is important). See assertBody(String, String, boolean)
        • The Mime Type equals the expected one (order is important). See assertMimetype(ExpectedContent, String)

      • assertSimilar

        public static void assertSimilar(ExpectedEmail expectedEmail,
                                 javax.mail.Message actualEmail)
                          throws javax.mail.MessagingException
        Assert that the fields of the received email are equal to the expected values. The expected email contains only one part (only one content). It will check that:
        • The received headers are respected (see assertHeaders(ExpectedEmailHeader, Message))
        • The body equals the expected one (order is important). See assertBody(String, String, boolean)
        • The Mime Type equals the expected one (order is important). See assertMimetype(ExpectedContent, String)

        The checking of the body ignores the new line characters.

        Parameters:
        expectedEmail - all the fields with their expected values
        actualEmail - the received email

      • assertEquals

        public static void assertEquals(ExpectedMultiPartEmail expectedEmail,
                                javax.mail.Message actualEmail,
                                boolean strict)
                         throws javax.mail.MessagingException,
                                IOException
        Assert that the fields of the received email are equal to the expected values. The expected email contains several parts (several contents). The received email should also have the equivalent parts. It will check that:
        • The received headers are respected (see assertHeaders(ExpectedEmailHeader, Message))
        • The received message is a Multipart email
        • The number of parts are equal
        • Each received part body equals the expected one (order is important). See assertBody(String, String, boolean)
        • Each received part Mime Type equals the expected one (order is important). See assertMimetype(ExpectedContent, String)

        The checking of the body may be done either strictly (totally equal) or not (new line characters are ignored).

        Parameters:
        expectedEmail - all the fields with their expected values
        actualEmail - the received email
        strict - true for strict checking (totally equals) or false to ignore new line characters in body contents
        Throws:
        javax.mail.MessagingException - when accessing the received email fails
        IOException - when reading the content of the email fails

      • assertEquals

        public static void assertEquals(ExpectedEmail expectedEmail,
                                javax.mail.Message actualEmail,
                                boolean strict)
                         throws javax.mail.MessagingException
        Assert that the fields of the received email are equal to the expected values. The expected email contains only one part (only one content). It will check that:
        • The received headers are respected (see assertHeaders(ExpectedEmailHeader, Message))
        • The body equals the expected one (order is important). See assertBody(String, String, boolean)
        • The Mime Type equals the expected one (order is important). See assertMimetype(ExpectedContent, String)

        The checking of the body may be done either strictly (totally equal) or not (new line characters are ignored).

        Parameters:
        expectedEmail - all the fields with their expected values
        actualEmail - the received email
        strict - true for strict checking (totally equals) or false to ignore new line characters in body contents
        Throws:
        javax.mail.MessagingException - when accessing the received email fails

      • assertMimetype

        public static void assertMimetype(ExpectedContent expectedContent,
                                  javax.mail.Message actualEmail)
                           throws javax.mail.MessagingException
        Checks that the received Mime Type for the message is like the expected Mime Type. The expected Mime Type is a regular expression.
        Parameters:
        expectedContent - the expected email content that contains the expected Mime Type as regular expression
        actualEmail - the received email to check
        Throws:
        javax.mail.MessagingException - when accessing the received email fails
